last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89785819
I acknowledge that baiting and using Ctrl+F to find the reply count was always part of the game for some people, but making it explicit makes it the default and creates a default dopamine hit from replies. It feels different. I liked the site when it has fewer features, using noko was fine too; any user would have to at least read the FAQ and figure out the site a little, and powerusers could always use 4chanX and add features as they wanted, but the default experience being as simple as possible felt like the right mix of open to new users without total spoonfeeding.

threads.com: What's the best chair for someone who spends 16+ hours a day 7 days a week sitting in front of a computer? Is the aeron really worth the money?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89782475
If you masturbate in your chair then the best chair is the fully loaded aeron remastered. well not even fully loaded but it must have forward tilt.
If you do not masturbate in the chair then get the mirra 2 with forward tilt. While just sitting upright say typing or whatever, standard sitting position, mirra is more supportive and comfortable but you can't spread your legs without the plastic seat pan digging into them.
Really there's almost no other options outside of some OEM global furniture group/neutral posture mechanism based chairs that have properly implemented forward tilt and it is the reason you get a better chair than a staples cheapo.
The blood flow thing may sound like a meme but it's not. It's actually noticable. Most importantly though if you were playing an intense game like osu or raising in WoW it's just so much more comfortable. It also makes typing with your wrists hovering easier.
If you do choose to go with a shit chair without forward tilt make sure you get a good foot rest that tilts and a angle adjustable desk/kb tray. This effectively achieves the same thing by tilting the floor and kbm relative to you rather than vice versa.

threads.com:
>Upgrade & Build Advice
Post build list or current specs including MONITOR: https://pcpartpicker.com/
Provide specific use cases (e.g. 4K editing, high FPS gaming)
State budget and country

>News
New releases: RTX 4090; AM5 / Zen 4; Intel Arc GPUs A770 and A750
RTX 4080 16GB (AD103) $1200 Nov Launch; RTX "4080" 12GB (AD104) unlaunched
Raptor Lake: K SKUs released + reviewed

>CPUs
For light usage, consider an Intel i3 or Ryzen 3/G.
For gaming, consider an Intel i5 (K if you want overclocking) or a Ryzen 5.
For multithreaded performance, consider an Intel i7 or a Ryzen 9. Get a Threadripper for heavy-duty workloads.
Avoid Zen4 (Ryzen 7000 series) - massively overpriced motherboards and poor-performing DDR5.

>GPUs
For gaming, check out the benchmarks for whatever games you play and pick whatever performs best.
For productivity, you will want to buy a Nvidia Card for CUDA, nvenc, better software support in general.

>PSUs
https://cultists.network/140/psu-tier-list/

>SSDs
Use an NVMe Drive for your operating system.
Standouts: Samsung 990 Pro, Crucial P5 Plus, Kingston KC3000, WD Black SN770
https://ssd.borecraft.com/
Don't buy HDDs for a desktop PC. If you need large scale storage, consider buying cloud storage or a NAS.

>Motherboard:

You don't need to switch ISPs, they will all know who you are anyway based on your payments and residence. You can limit what they know about you by using a 3rd party DNS provider that also supported encrypted DoT or DoH, and also only browsing HTTPS websites. If you want to hide more from them then a VPN or Tor remain an option but personally I think that is an overkill threat model to use a VPN or Tor 24/7

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89784131
Using VPN/Tor a lot is helpful for more than your ISP though, it also keeps you less identifiable when browsing websites. If you live in a less populated state odds are high you're the only person from your ISP visiting non-mainstream sites, even if your IP changes periodically they can still safely assume it's you. Tor Browser especially would help with that with its fingerprinting protections.

Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics OEM activation to generate a permanent legitimate license.

>>Which version should I install?
>Education/Enterprise
Can disable telemetry and delay updates a year.
>LTSC / IoT LTSC
LTSC = 5 years support, VL/KMS only
IoT LTSC = 10 years support, HWID only
Comes with Win32 system apps, no MS Store, no feature updates, security updates only.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: 
wsreset -i


>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 10/2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC lasts until 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Installs a KMS server emulator, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free. As a last resort, you can try LibreOffice and set it to save as Office file formats.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89784347
The price of airline tickets is complex. Fuel is a major cost but it is not the only one. Most obviously there's also cost of employees (Pilots, flight attendants, plane maintenance, gate agents, baggage handlers, and so on). Most of these marginal costs are incurred on a per-flight basis meaning there will be incentive for the airline to keep supply as low as possible and optimize revenue on each flight. One obvious dynamic here is jacking up the price when there are only a few remaining seats on the plane, because unless there's enough demand for another full flight, it's far better to just squeeze as much as possible from a few more passengers who really need to get that flight. Planes are also physical objects that stay where they are flown until they are moved (incurring more costs), yet another constraint airlines must consider when deciding how many flights to run between locations.

High fuel cost can cause airlines to cut flights, reducing supply which will subsequently lead to an increase in ticket prices, but it's one of many important factors.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89784672
>Stupid question from C# dev - couldn't all of this be avoided if you use static linking and ship your C lib with your application code?
You sound normal and this is a legit question I will take a break from shitposting and give you a real answer
The problem (on major operating systems) is that the system's C library is the only stable interface for communicating with the kernel
Trying to bypass it will just break all kinds of shit in insane ways because a new OS version (even if it's a minor update) can change the kernel syscall interface
They found this out the hard way with Go and finally gave up and went back to dynamically linking libc

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89785083

>The problem (on major operating systems) is that the system's C library is the only stable interface for communicating with the kernel
This is definitely a problem with Windows, but not *as much* with Linux. Technically speaking, all Linux syscall numbers are fixed. You could issue the syscall instruction in your own code, and not use a system libc to talk to the kernel.

threads.name: /hsg/ Home Server General Pfsense ed.
threads.com:
No /hsg/ thread currently so I'm making one.

READ THE WIKI! & help by contributing:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server

>NAS Case Guide. Feel free to add to it:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server/Case_guide

/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. Know all about NAS? Learn virtualization. Spun up some VMs? Learn about networking by standing up a OPNsense/pfsense box and configuring some VLANs. There's always more to learn and chances to grow. Think you’re god-tier already? Setup OpenStack and report back.

>What software should I run?
Install Gentoo. Or whatever flavor of *nix is best for the job or most comfy for you. Jellyfin to replace Netflix, nextcloud to replace Googlel, ampache to replace spotify, the list goes on and on. Look at the awesome self-hosted list and ask.

>Why should I have a home server?
Learn something new. De-botnet your life. Serving applications to yourself, your family, and your frens feels good. Put your /g/ skills to good use for yourself and those close to you. Store their data with proper availability redundancy and backups and serve it back to them with a /comfy/ easy to use interface.

>Links & resources
Server tips: https://anonbin.io/?1759c178f98f6135#CzLuPx4s2P7zuExQBVv5XeDkzQSDeVkZMWVhuecemeN6
RouterOS's: https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server#Custom
https://github.com/Kickball/awesome-selfhosted
https://www.labgopher.com
https://wiki.debian.org/FreedomBox/Features
List of ARM-based SBCs: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1PGaVu0sPBEy5GgLM8N-CvHB2FESdlfBOdQKqLziJLhQ
Low-power x86 systems: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1yl414kIy9MhaM0-VrpCqjcsnfofo95M1smRTuKN6e-E
Cheap disks: https://shucks.top/ & https://diskprices.com/
